Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y9W-G231-JBCN-43CW-00000-00From the Executive Director: The Time for Internet Privacy Legislation Is Long Overdue2020-02-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:25ZLexisNexisEXECUTIVE DIRECTORFrom the Executive Director: The Time for Internet Privacy Legislation Is Long OverdueP.C. Editor

This past year, the Japanese American Citizens League celebrated its 90th anniversary. In about one-third of that time, in just the past 30-40 years, we have seen a revolution in technology as the Internet has gone from the early telephone modems to modern Gigabit and wireless technology, making Internet access present in all facets of our lives.

As consumers, we also know that our relationship to digital services is as complex as it is important. We use the Internet to do everything from connecting to friends and family to seeking new employment and educational opportunities.

As our dependence on the Internet has grown, so, too, has the power of Big Tech companies such as Amazon, Facebook and Google. These are no longer start-up companies in need of special support to foster growth. It is past time for Congress to properly regulate these companies and others to protect our privacy as consumers, whose data is increasingly becoming a profit center for the tech companies.

The Internet has infiltrated all aspects of our lives, and with that, the reach of the companies we interact with are also embedded in everything we do. Search engines and e-commerce sites may now know more details about us than our own spouses. Yet, that information can also be used by those companies to create a more efficient and quality Internet experience for us as consumers.

Facebook and Google are masters at tailoring our Internet experience based on whom we interact with, what we search for and what links we follow. The question is how can we ensure our information is used appropriately to improve the Internet experience and not weaponized against us by either the private or public sector.

Given the ubiquity of the Internet in every facet of our lives and the danger of how much of our information is available outside of our individual control, it is past time that there be some regulation of Internet privacy.

Any regulation must keep in mind the principles of free speech and freedom of association that enable platforms like Facebook to foster the development of communities like JACL's online presence.

As a national organization, we recognize the need to regulate the Internet experience at the national level. In the absence of Federal privacy legislation, we are seeing states begin to implement their own legislation.

It is past time that Congress act to enact privacy standards for all companies to follow, regardless of where they are located or their users are located. A single standard removes the uncertainty of what laws are applicable, even to an organization like JACL, which must protect the information of our own members and web users as we increasingly interact through the Internet.

It has been almost four years since the European Union passed its General Data Protection Regulation and nearly two years since it went into effect. If 27 different nations can agree on basic Internet protections, it is hard to understand why our Congress is unable, or perhaps more accurately, is unwilling to act.

There was a time when one could argue that the absence of regulation fostered innovation and the expansion of the Internet. That time is long past. The Internet is no longer the domain of small start-ups, but of the Big Tech companies that control our personal information.

We can create regulation that allows innovation to continue but also institutes standardized guardrails for all of us to follow. Too much power rests with Big Tech in how our information can be used, and the consumer must be returned the right of that control.

We must make sure that our data is not abused, or even worse, weaponized against us as it has in the past. At one time, the census was used against Japanese Americans, but as a result, we now have regulations to prevent such abuses from happening. Similar regulations to protect our private information must now be implemented to protect our information, now much more detailed than anything available through the census.

The Internet is tremendously powerful, something unimaginable even 40 years ago. Because of that growth, it is now an indispensable part of our lives, one that we cannot simply opt out. We need Congress to ensure that everyone has equal access to the Internet without fear that our personal information is being misused or abused.

David Inoue is executive director of the JACL. He is based at the organization's Washington, D.C., office.

David Inoue

urn:contentItem:5DFS-W641-JCBD-Y53P-00000-00FROM THE FIRST EDITIONS:2014-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:25ZLexisNexisHOME NEWSFROM THE FIRST EDITIONS:

STAR:

COWELL - I WILL AXE BORING RUDE CHERYL

X Factor judge Cheryl Fernandez-Versini faces the sack next year if she keeps clashing with boss Simon Cowell.

13YR HELL IS ENDED

British forces handed over Camp Bastion to the Afghan Army yesterday in emotional scenes after 13 years of bloody war.

3 DIE IN BRIT SURF

Three surfers died yesterday after getting into difficulty off the coast of Newquay, Cornwall.

Sport:

ROBIN VAN SHIRTY

Robin van Persie rescued Manchester United with a last ditch goal, but then got called ``stupid'' by his boss.

MO'S SPURS BLAST

Mauricio Pochettino blasted Tottenham for losing their heads in a shock home defeat to Newcastle.

EXPRESS:

HOW TO BEAT MEMORY LOSS

Drinking a hot cup of cocoa at bedtime could be the key to beating memory loss.

EU MIGRANTS PUTTING TOWNS 'UNDER SIEGE'

A cabinet minister has claimed that some towns in Britain are ``swamped'' and ``under siege'' from huge numbers of EU migrants.

STRICTLY FUN FACTOR SAVES JUDY, BUT THOM'S BOOTED OFF

Fans voted for the fun factor on Strictly Come Dancing last night giving Judy Murray plenty of support to keep her on the show.

Sport:

CAPTAIN STUPID

Robin van Persie warned Chelsea that Manchester United can catch them in the title race - but was then branded ``stupid'' by Louis van Gaal.

INJURIES WON'T MAKE STURRIDGE EURO STAR

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers claims Daniel Sturridge will never become one of the best strikers in Europe unless he can overcome his constant injury problems.

TELEGRAPH:

QUIETLY, THE LONG WAR ENDS

The soldiers snapped to attention and a Union flag was lowered towards the parched desert sand.

WANTED: SELF-STARTER TO CLIMB 3,000FT EVERY DAY

As occupations go, it probably beats sitting in front of a computer screen for eight hours a day.

TORY CABINET MINISTER SAYS TOWNS FLOODED BY IMMIGRANTS

Towns are being ``swamped'' by immigrant workers, Michael Fallon said yesterday, in the most outspoken comments on the issue yet by a Conservative Cabinet minister.

City:

BRITAIN'S LEADING BANKS WITHSTAND ECB 'STRESS TESTS'

Dozens of European banks have failed a healthcheck set by regulators to test lenders' ability to withstand another financial crisis.

VODAFONE'S £6BN TAKEOVER OF ONO DOGGED BY TAX FRAUD ALLEGATIONS

Vodafone's £6bn acquisition of Ono has been tarnished by allegations that the Spanish cable operator's profits were inflated by tax fraud.

MIRROR:

OUT AT LAST

British troops launch one final attack on the Taliban - just hours before the end of combat operations in Afghanistan.

DEAD BRIT JIHADI 'TOO SCARED TO COME HOME'

A fourth jihadist fighter from one British city killed in Syria wanted to come home but was too frightened of the backlash, his family claimed.

I'M GUTTED TO GET EARLY BATH

Ex-rugby star Thom Evans has revealed his disappointment after being kicked off Strictly Come Dancing last night.

Sport:

SHIRT AND SWEET

Robin Van Persie scored a dramatic 93rd-minute equaliser - only to be branded ``stupid'' by boss Louis van Gaal.

HAIRDRYER PAYS OFF FOR PARDS

Alan Pardew gave his players a half-time rollicking - and it paid off in just seven seconds.

TIMES:

BRITAIN ENDS ITS AFGHAN WAR

Britain's long war in Afghanistan ended yesterday, with an admission that the country might never be safe.

HALF-TERM HORROR AS THREE DIE IN CORNWALL SURFING TRAGEDY

A half-term outing to the beach went horribly wrong yesterday when two men and a woman were killed surfing while four children with them escaped with their lives.

TOWNS ARE SWAMPED BY MIGRANTS, SAYS MINISTER

David Cameron has slapped down a cabinet minister who claimed towns were ``swamped'' by EU migrants as Germany deepened its opposition to proposals to limit numbers.

City:

ITALY HEADS LEAGUE OF BANKING SHAME

Fourteen of Europe's largest banks have failed ``stress tests'' designed to assess the ability of big lenders to withstand a financial crisis and have been ordered to raise nearly 10 billion Euros to plug a shortfall in their balance sheets.

MRS HAVERSHAM RETURNS WITH EVEN GREATER EXPECTATIONS

The former chairwoman of Stobart, who quit the trucking company after a power struggle is back with a bang in the City with an automotive start-up aiming at takeovers of up to £1 billion.

MAIL:

NOT A TRACE LEFT BEHIND

They served their country with honour and courage - and 453 paid the ultimate price. But, after 13 years of bloodshed, there will be no memorial in Afghanistan to mark the troops' sacrifice.

ED 'COULD SNATCH DEFEAT FROM THE JAWS OF VICTORY'

Ed Miliband has been warned he faces 'catastrophe' at the next election if Labour in Scotland continues to haemorrhage support to the nationalists.

MOVE OVER CHERYL & CO, AT AGE OF 69, DAME HELEN IS NEW FACE OF L'OREAL

She is living proof that age need be no barrier to glamour. And Dame Helen Mirren's enviable appearance has now earned her a high profile new role.

City:

IT'S LVG TIME!

Louis van Gaal claimed Manchester United's fighting spirit will take them back into the top four after Robin van Persie's last-minute equaliser against Chelsea.

PARDEW'S QUICK FIX

Alan Pardew saw his half-time rant pay off instantly as Newcastle fought back to beat Tottenham 2-1 and climb out of the relegation zone yesterday.

INDEPENDENT:

UKIP 'EXPLOITING GROOMING SCANDAL' TO SECURE PARTY'S FIRST POLICE CHIEF

Ukip has been accused of exploiting the misery of Rotherham sex-abuse victims in its determination to win its first police and crime commissioner.

THE LAST EXIT

After the overthrow of the Taliban in 2001, Tony Blair declared that the West would not walk away from Afghanistan. Now, with tumbleweed blowing through Camp Bastion, we will see if that promise is to be kept.

THE 200,000 SYRIAN CHILD REFUGEES FORCED INTO SLAVE LABOUR IN LEBANON

Eleven-year-old Abdullah was working on a construction site last week when he accidentally swallowed a rusty nail. He was one of up to 200,000 Syrian refugee children - some as young as five - working in Lebanon's potato and bean fields or picking figs in the Bekaa Valley. Many of them are beaten with sticks in a situation perilously close to slave labour. And when their country's cancerous war ends, they will be the new men and women who will have to return to rebuild their nation.

City:

ITALIAN BANKS' CAPITAL HOLE EXPOSED BY EUROPEAN FINANCIAL STRESS TEST

Italian banks must launch a fundraising drive as a result of the European authorities' landmark assessment of the health of the Continent's financial sector.

BUSINESS RATES KEEP HIGH-STREET SHOPS EMPTY

Britain's dysfunctional business rates regime Is helping to keep high-street shops empty, according to campaigners.

i:

UK RIFT WITH BRUSSELS WIDENS

David Cameron the most serious confrontation with the European Union of his premiership amid a fresh row with Germany over immigration curbs and growing fury over a Brussels demand for more money.

AFTER 13 YEARS, BRITAIN LEAVES AFGHANISTAN

'Please don't call it our Dien Bien Phu``, Lieutenant-Colonel Simon Winkworth of the Royal Engineers asked as we gazed on to a desolate expanse of scrub and sand, on which he was going to build Camp Bastion.

MANCHESTER TO LEEDS IN JUST 26 MINUTES WITH HS3

Rail journey times between England's biggest cities in the North would be halved under plans published today for new high-speed rail services across the Pennines.

City:

ECB STRESS TESTS HIGHLIGHT PLIGHT OF ITALIAN BANKS

Italian banks must launch a fundraising drive as a result of the European authorities' landmark assessment of the health of the Continent's financial sector.

NEXT GOOGLE 'TO COME FROM DEVELOPING WORLD'

A Silicon Valley entrepreneur turned investor who sold his company to Amazon for 970m dollars (£600m) believes the next Google or Amazon will come from the developing world rather than the US or UK.

GUARDIAN:

MIGRANTS ROW LEAVES TORIES IN DISARRAY

Michael Fallon, the defence secretary, has claimed British towns are being ``swamped'' by immigrants and their residents are ``under siege'', in an escalation of the emotive language being used Tory ministers calling for a renegotiation of the UK's relationship with Europe.

FLAG COMES DOWN ON 13-YEAR WAR IN AFGHANISTAN

Two British soldiers lowered the union flag in Helmand province yesterday, marking the end of British combat in Afghanistan. The ceremony, at the Camp Bastion-Leatherneck complex, officially brought to a close one of the longest and fiercest conflicts UK troops have been engaged in since the end of the second world war. The British death toll stands at 453.

CITY UNDER STRAIN AFTER DEATH OF FOURTH PORTSMOUTH JIHADI

Pressure is growing inside and outside the Bangladeshi community in Portsmouth for its leaders to act against further radicalisation following the reported death of a fourth young man from the city who went to fight for Islamic State in Syria.

City:

HEALTH CHECK FINDS 24 EU BANKS AILING - BUT THE UK'S PASS MUSTER

Britain's major banks have passed a Europe-wide health check - although Lloyds Banking Group will face scrutiny tomorrow when it outlines plans to cut up to 9,000 jobs and axe branches under a three-year plan intended to bolster its profitability.

TESCO CHIEFS GO ON BUDGET HOLIDAY TO 'RECONNECT'

First he ordered managers back to the shop floor so they could ``reconnect'' with customers. Now Dave Lewis, the new boss of Tesco, has taken his top executives on a cut-price mini-break, where they were forced to do their own shopping, cooking and washing up.

FINANCIAL TIMES:

ITALY COMES UNDER PRESSURE AFTER NINE BANKS FAIL ECB STRESS TEST

Italy's central bank was thrown on the defensive yesterday as its banking sector emerged as the standout loser in health checks aimed at restoring confidence in the euro area's financial sector.

BALLMER SCORES SLAM DUNK ON CLIPPER PURCHASE WITH TAX PERKS WORTH 1BN DOLLARS

Steve Ballmer stands to gain about 1bn dollars in tax benefits as a result of his 2bn dollar purchase of the Los Angeles Clippers basketball team, helping to explain why the Microsoft billionaire paid a record price for the club.

LAMONT'S BITTER EXIT OFFERS PARTY REVIVAL CHANCE

The departure of Johann Lamont, Scottish Labour leader, was a gift for the party's nationalist opponents, who have long-sought to paint it as London-dominated and out of touch.

City:

BIG TECH START-UPS BYPASS SILICON VALLEY

Most tech start-ups that have gained a 1bn dollar valuation in the past decade hailed from outside Silicon Valley, according to research that casts new light on the global growth of fledgling digital companies.

EM SHARES SUFFER AMID GLOBAL FLUX

Global market turbulence has triggered the biggest outflows from entering emerging market equities in more than a year.

SUN:

THE KATE EX SCRAPE

Corrie's Kate Ford was caught up in a foul-mouthed 10pm slanging match at her home - between a male friend, his ex and his lover.

PRIDE IN RETREAT

The Union flag is lowered to finally end Britain's war in Afghanistan after 13 years and 453 troops lost.

GIGS AGED 103? THAT IS UNUSUAL

Veteran singer Sir Tom Jones reckons he will still be doing gigs in 2043 - when he will be 103.

Sport:

STUPID

Robin van Persie's boss branded him stupid after his last-gasp equaliser.

RIO 'UNSURE' ON RETIREMENT

Rio Ferdinand has not decided whether to retire after all.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60N8-1461-JBSN-32HJ-00000-00From Trump to Zuckerberg: How profit, not ideology, guided the attack on TikTok2020-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:25ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1From Trump to Zuckerberg: How profit, not ideology, guided the attack on TikTok

One surprising ally in Facebook's war against TikTok is U.S. President Donald Trump, who has a long history of oppressing Chinese tech companies like Huawei. Some may joke that Trump's rage stems from when K-pop fans and TikTok users pranked his Tulsa rally in June. But the real reason for his hostility may be the hawkish stance this administration has long taken on China.

Huawei, the world's biggest maker of smartphones and network equipment, is China's first global tech brand taking to the international market. Sensing a threat, the Trump administration has moved to cut off Huawei's access to chips and other technology. It has also barred federal funds from being used for Huawei equipment in U.S. networks. Branding Huawei as a data breach concern, Trump also encouraged allies to ban Huawei.

This is all too similar to Trump's current attack on TikTok and WeChat, which is rooted not only in security concerns or anger toward Beijing, but also in something deeper: Trump's entire "America First" agenda, his xenophobic base and his tanking approval rating.

Because of the pandemic, mass unemployment and a national reckoning with centuries of racism, Trump's approval ratings have been lower in 2020 than late 2019. Building an image of a common enemy is his usual move to divert the public's attention away from everything that's going wrong.

Much like the British ban on Huawei, an obvious result of American influence, the actual impact of Trump's executive order is at best dubious and at worst counterproductive. It is generally interpreted as a ban on transactions through WeChat. But can users still text, just not pay, through WeChat? Does this ban apply only to WeChat or to all Tencent-related transactions?

Furthermore, much like Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods, this ban hurts American companies and consumers as well. If Apple does not allow devices to download WeChat, it risks losing a majority of the Chinese consumer market. Tencent also has numerous American investments and partnerships, making its transactions valuable for the American economy.

Although this order does more damage than good, Trump's approval ratings geared upward after his contentious attack on China.

This is why Trump doesn't care that his whimsical executive order impedes globalization or damages the already crumbling U.S. economy as long as the federal government can gain "key money" from Microsoft's buyout of TikTok.

Trump simply wants to paint a reality television-style story of Chinese tech companies being the bad guys, hurting the U.S. and being screwed over by the wit of his administration.

Interestingly, Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Facebook, agrees with Trump's attack against TikTok. This is not the first time the two have fought on the same side. Facebook has long facilitated Trump's agenda, and its lack of content moderation helps disseminate misinformation relating to the pandemic. Conspiracy theories have been circulating on Facebook pretty much unchecked. A major reason behind this, besides little investment in content moderation, is that the company's dominance of social media, along with a regulatory vacuum, allows Facebook to profit at the expense of users' privacy and the truth. Not regulating the content costs society, not Facebook.

As Chairman David Cicilline of House subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law noted, "Facebook hosts or enables countless pages and ads that are dedicated to conspiracy theories and calls to violence, including content that led to the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville in 2017." According to Cicilline, Facebook can get away with this because "there's no competition forcing" Facebook to "police" itself.

And so the Trump administration, after years of visa restrictions on and trade war against China, is now focusing on the battlefield of the internet, where Big Tech CEOs wield excessive power, as revealed in the Congress hearing on July 29. Zuckerberg was the only CEO to openly accuse Chinese media companies of espionage and information theft. This is ironic considering the actual evidence-based accusations of privacy violations against Facebook that the hearing unveiled.

Additionally, Facebook has bought up growing rivals to secure its market dominance. In 2012, while discussing buying Instagram, Zuckerberg wrote, "One thing about startups though is you can often acquire them." And this principle may be why TikTok is so overtly attacked by Facebook, whose launch of a copycat feature Instagram Reels instantly made Zuckerberg a "centibillionaire."

All this proves that profit, not ideology, guides the attack on Chinese tech companies like TikTok. What these attackers ignore is who would suffer from the TikTok and WeChat ban: the students who depend on these companies for communication with their families or the low-income Americans who depend on these companies for employment.

My hope is that, instead of bowing to Trump's Sinophobia, people will look past stereotypes of Chinese people as espionage risks or of Chinese technology as "a threat to national security." After all, this country is supposed to stand for tolerance and diversity, not Trump or Zuckerberg's businessman mindset.

urn:contentItem:5Y0P-TSN1-JCMN-Y3T7-00000-00From Venture capital to growth equity - Founders perspective on today's capital markets2020-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:26ZLexisNexisFrom Venture capital to growth equity - Founders perspective on today's capital marketsBusiness Matters

Jan 16, 2020( Business Matters: http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/ Delivered by Newstex)   https://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/business/from-venture-capital-to-growth-equity-founders-perspective-on-todays-capital-markets/In December 2019, one thousand plus leaders from the finance, investment, and policymaking industries came together for the SALT leadership forum, a two-day event held in Abu Dhabi.The panel 'From Venture Capital to Growth Equity - Founders Perspective on Today's Capital Markets,' featured moderation by founder and CEO of Farvahar Partners[1], Omeed Malik. Farvahar Partners is a boutique investment company with specialized interest in private start-ups valued at over one billion dollars, also known as 'unicorns.' The panel features start-up founders Ben Hindman (Splash), Cheih Huang (Boxed), Ryan Denehy (Electric), and Dan Teran (Managed by Q). Play Video[2]All five men provided their shrewd insights on a variety of topics regarding investing in the private sector, which can be found transcribed below.

Omeed Malik:Well, thanks for coming. This is great to be here in Abu Dhabi, and I want to thank the whole SALT team for another great conference. I've been involved with them for almost a decade, and this is the first time in the Middle East and I'm sure there will be many more to come. I'm really pleased to be here with friends of mine. I think we're the only panel that's actually operators, is that correct? Ben Hindman: Sounds about right. Omeed Malik: It's mostly managers, yeah. Just to set the stage briefly and kind of frame the conversation, the private market has exploded over the last five years and that's due to a variety of reasons — there are macroeconomic ones, regulatory ones — most people point to the fact that the maximum amount of public companies we had was in 1996. We're down about 50% off the highs of publicly traded companies. That can be attributed to Sarbanes-Oxley, the JOBS Act of 2012, and then during that same period of time, additional capital coming from the Middle East and Asia into these private businesses, so there's a plethora of reasons as to why it's happening. But we thought it would be an interesting idea to bring some of these future unicorns out to the Middle East — to this region — because often the investors in this region don't see them until it's too late or they miss the opportunity. So that was kind of the impetus and the genesis for why this panel was put together and I think it's going to be the beginning of hopefully many other times that you guys come out here. I think just to get started, when you think of how a company begins it always starts with a great idea, so there's that 'eureka' moment that someone has in order to start a company. So, in a way to kind of flesh out what you guys all do, if you could introduce yourselves, but also go into when that eureka moment happened for you and where you were and why you thought you needed to start your business. So do you want to start Ben? Ben Hindman:Great, I'll go fast. My name is Ben Hindman, I'm the CEO and founder of Splash. Splash is an event marketing software targeted at the enterprise, and my origin story was that I was hosting events. I had thrown a mystery fly-away to Jamaica for JetBlue, and I could believe how much money was on the line for this event. We generated about a million dollars at one event and it was really that 'oh my gosh, this is a heck of an opportunity' and I started building a software for myself as an event marketer, and now my software powers all of the events for Airbnb, LinkedIn, Salesforce, Facebook, and Spotify to name a few. So we are the system of record for all of their events, and it happened because I needed it — I built it for myself. Cheih Huang:Hey everyone my name's Cheih, I'm one of the co-founders and CEO of a company called Boxed. I grew up in a place that's otherwise known as the cradle of civilization: New Jersey, and so — Omeed Malik: Either that or Mesopotamia I'm not sure. Cheih Huang:Yeah, well we're number two, we're the other cradle of civilization. I just remember being in Costco one day, you know every single — every other weekend I'd go with my parents to Costco growing up and I just thought as an adult it kind of sucked lugging all of this stuff home, and this was almost six plus years ago when I thought 'oh my gosh with the rise of mobile why isn't anyone doing this online' in terms of just focusing on B2C and B2B and the big bulk quantities and so that's how we got started. We got started literally in a garage in central New Jersey about six years ago, and since then we've sold over half a billion dollars worth of merchandise and now it's been a really fun kind of experience. Focusing like I said not only on B2C but also B2B as well. Most folks if you ever fly into the US for example, you're probably customers of Boxed without knowing it. We now service every single public airport in America, all the major airlines use us, and so it's not just B2C these days. Ryan Denehy:I can attest to the fact — my company has bought thousands of rolls of paper towels from Boxed. My name is Ryan, I run a company called Electric. We do outsourced IT support for companies that don't have their own in-house IT departments and we're automating most of the manual labor that goes into running an IT department for these companies. I got the idea when I was running my previous start-up, and our internet went out and the IT consultant that we were paying thousands of dollars a month to allegedly look after this stuff was nowhere to be found, and the internet was out for so long that we had to send our sales team home for a day and a half. The whole time the internet was down and this IT guy was AWOL on us we were losing revenue, and so I kind of looked around at all these different back office functions whether it was HR or accounting or insurance. All of these different back office utilities were being reinvented with software and delivered in a much more efficient and user-friendly way than when they're delivered as a service, but nobody was doing it for IT. That's when the lightbulb went off and I said 'this is a huge market, it's a badly needed solution, and I've gotta go out and start this' so that was three years ago. Dan Teran:I'm Dan Teran, I'm the founder of a company called Managed by Q. We help thousands of companies run their office operations. I started working in tech in New York City about a decade ago, and actually Ben and I met in one of the first co-working spaces — and of course now there's a million of them — in New York called Dogpatch Labs back in the day, and I had worked at a handful of start-ups in New York in various roles — at every company I saw the same set of problems which was the founders, the founder and CEO, the founding team, were spending a disproportionate amount of time trying to manage the office when they really should have been focused on their business. I saw this as my friends were starting companies, and so we really set out at Q to build — the original idea was this operating system for the physical space that could run the office with the reliability of software. So we set out about six years ago to build that, today we power office operations for about 1700 companies around the world including big companies like Uber, Lyft, Amazon and then thousands of start-ups. Omeed Malik:So Cheih, just going back to you, when I hear you describe your business — and obviously I'm familiar with it — it sounds like an online combination of Costco and Amazon put together, like they created this baby, and that's what you've started. Is that an accurate description? Are you comfortable with that? Cheih Huang:Probably not the most accurate description. Maybe they're bigger versions of Boxed I would say instead of vice versa. But for us I would say there's three main differentiation points. First is the buying experience. Most things — most companies in commerce when you buy online you're buying single items, so in the industry we call that spearfishing, and it works if you're buying that TV or the chair or most other long tail items, but when you get into consumer packaged goods that's not how people generally shop and if you're shipping a single item of CPG items across the country you're going to lose your ass pretty quickly on it and it's been a challenge for the industry. So for us, the average order value for if you just buy dry goods — it's 10 items at about $100 US dollars and if you buy fresh foods with it, it goes up to about 28 items per order and over $150 dollars is our average order value, so we can generate actual contribution margin, even though we're shipping low margin stuff. Second is our focus on B2B. Like I said before, we ship to every airport in America, a lot of huge companies as well — and hopefully to everyone on this panel as well — so that's something we specialize in, and how we win those contracts is through the software that we build ourselves. So we build procurement portals where you have the consumer buying experience coupled with an enterprise grade procurement rule software. So for example for all of your companies, especially if you're big giant companies, you're probably using procurement software that no one likes to use and looks like it was built during the Cold War. So for us we have that consumer buying experience, and that's why airlines and other big companies really like it. Third, is that we built the front end, middleware, as well as warehouse management software, and we even engineer and build our own robotics these days to automate our own fulfillment center. We airlift that entire software stack and we power big retailers around the world. One of our clients is the biggest retailer in Asia, so AEON Group — $83 billion dollar retailer — is in the middle of airlifting our entire software stack to help run some of their omnichannel. Omeed Malik:I visited your fulfillment center in New Jersey, and I was struck by how automated some of it was. How imperative is that to have an automated fulfillment center, or have that aspect of technology? Cheih Huang:In developed countries it's very important, because labor is obviously very expensive. Getting efficient with how you do things is really important. More and more across the entire world I think you're going to see a move to automation and especially if you're going into low-margin stuff. Every penny counts, and so if you can automate you really do have an advantage. Omeed Malik:Often when people decide whether they want to invest private, they don't necessarily need to see the exact same kind of company in the public markets, but they want some sort of precedent to give them comfort. Ryan, with Electric, is there a public market comp for what you do? It's obviously an innovative idea, but who do you compare yourself to, is there someone out there? Ryan Denehy:Yeah, we think about this all the time. I think Servicenow is probably the best public market comp for what we're doing. We see that alignment in a few ways. One, the vertical focus on IT service management software. We view what we're doing as a Servicenow-sized opportunity, but for the middle market, where as Servicenow is focused on the large enterprise. What they've proven is that a really neglected but large market like IT — if you apply really strict focus on delivering a great product for that very specific solution to that customer, and build a world class team around it and just continue to focus on that — that you can build a phenomenal business. Also similar to them, we don't have any competitors in our space at the moment, so my investors like to remind me that it's basically ours to lose at this point. Ben Hindman: How big is Servicenow? Ryan Denehy: I think they were — was a nine billion market cap company when they IPO'd a few years ago, and they trade at $55 billion now. Omeed Malik: And you're already a subscription business right? Ryan Denehy: Yes. Omeed Malik: So how do you scale it from here? What do you need to do? Ryan Denehy:Well I mean, I think like all of us on this panel, we like to think of ourselves as responsible stewards of capital, so just sort of buying your way into a market — some companies can do that — it's definitely not the path that we've chosen to take. We've had a very very strict focus on unit economics since day one, I think Cheih, your business, talking about margins, I mean if you didn't do that you wouldn't be able to still be in business. The scalability really just comes down to being smart about the nuts and bolts of the numbers and making sure that if you're spending a dollar to get a dollar fifty that you can maintain that over time. Omeed Malik:So Ben, you come up with this idea and then you execute it, but intuitively I would have thought that some of your clients might have wanted a build it yourself, but your clients are Amazon, Salesforce — rather than trying to get into the event game themselves, they're just hiring you. What does that tell you? Ben Hindman:It's pretty interesting to be on stage with Dan and with Ryan — my business and theirs are similar in that we are vertical specific solutions, and it kind of speaks in my mind — which you're pointing out — to where we're at in the software cycle. Salesforce IPO'd about 16 years ago, and they're about a $16 billion dollar business, and right now their ecosystem is about six thousand businesses on top of Salesforce's ecosystem — us being one of them — and it's allowing us to both scale into their ecosystem — use their ecosystem for growth — but also really focus on being really good at one user type. And so while sure, Salesforce or Facebook, LinkedIn — one of our customers — they could build this, but we're just going so deep and using their pipes to do it that they've kind of in a way forfeited the market, identified us as best in class, and hire us, but also kind of go to market with us. And so I do think that's where you're going to start to see moving forward — businesses that hyper-target on a user type, automate or give the best in class tools to that user, and really then scaling, grow, and become the industry standard for that vertical. Omeed Malik: So we're at a conference, should the SALT conference use your service? Ben Hindman:Yeah, and the app is terrible. I also love that these are our customers, because it speaks — I mean we are seeing an increase in face to face marketing. Digital is saturated, it's really hard for our customers, it's hard to drive deals in digital. I've had really powerful conversations at this conference — a lot of cards — these pieces of paper you throw away. While I do think in a lot of ways you've seen a lot of software that has tried to automate and make this experience more fluid, I just don't think we've even seen the beginning of the in-person or face-to face solution era. I think in the next couple years you're going to start to see data, and cheaper screens and automation just completely take this over this type of sowing experience. Omeed Malik:It is crazy how it seems so antiquated that we hand people these cards but that's great that you're thinking ahead about it. So Dan, you were a successful CEO, I think you raised about $100 million dollars for this business, and then you sold it this past April to a small company called WeWork I think for about $220 million dollars. So tell us a little about the thought process there and that sale, and then as a result of that sale you didn't just go away, you actually went and had a front row seat — you worked at WeWork reporting to the CEO correct? Dan Teran:Correct. I've known Adam and Miguel the founders of WeWork for a number of years now and it was — I would say — a long courtship that unfortunately did not make for a long marriage. We'd been having a conversation for a number of years and in April made the decision to join them, the reported price was $220 million dollars and we thought it was a really good deal for our team and for our investors, but I would say more importantly at the time we were highly convicted that their scale and platform and access to capital was going to give us an opportunity to realize the next chapter for our business. As Omeed alluded to, I joined their leadership team running corporate development so I ran M...investments and partnerships, as well as the platform of acquired companies at WeWork, and then about a month and a half ago made the decision to move on and focus full-time on making an effort to buy my company back from WeWork. Obviously things didn't pan out quite the way we had intended there, but are still super excited about our business and fortunately have found a lot of support from the investment community to make Managed Q an independent company again. Omeed Malik:So just to be clear, you're now in a process of buying back a company you sold less than eight months later? Dan Teran:Yeah correct. Omeed Malik:Okay. And I'm assuming you're getting a pretty healthy discount? Dan Teran:You can infer from WeWork's current situation that they're — Omeed Malik:Okay moving on, thanks for that. We bring up WeWork, but it looks like the whole WeWork situation has created a bit of a correction in the private market. We'd be remiss if we didn't mention that but in a way — at least in my own opinion, I'd love to hear yours — it's healthy. You did need a bit of a correction in a market that had gone frothy and if anything else what we hear most from investors is we don't want companies that are just going to buy growth, we want to hear about a path to profitability. For all of you, how much is that factoring into your day to day? Dan Teran:I think six months ago I would have told you that I was never going to have to raise capital again, and six months later I'm in the middle of another capital raise, and so I have a pretty good sense of what market we're looking for right now. I think to your point Omeed, there's been a very healthy shift of fundamentals which tends to kind of happen on a cycle, and I think it's preventing a much larger shake out from occurring, this is sort of like a bit of a shock to the system'\? You're seeing founders respond, react, and adjust their plans because the markets are telling them we want to see profitability, we want to see strong fundamentals. We've made significant changes to our plan and are super excited about being profitable in the near future as we re-emerge as an independent company. I would also say for pretty much all of our businesses on stage here, this kind of tailwind of focusing on efficiency, profitability, is also giving a lot of life to companies that help other companies do that, so Ryan makes your IT more efficient, Ben makes your events management more efficient, Cheih helps you reduce your spend on essentials, we help you run your workplace more efficiently, so we're actually seeing a lot of demand from the market for products and services that are going to help businesses scale more efficiently. Cheih Huang:I can attest to that. We only have in our company if you count every single person we run payroll for, it's probably five or six hundred people these days and we have one full-time IT person — because we use Electric — so it's about as efficient as you can get because you can't take that to zero. Ben Hindman:Just to throw it out there, while certainly profitability matters, and I think certainly every time we fundraise nowadays we're looking to find that profitability. The types of acquisitions that we're seeing based off of growth rate are pretty astounding, at least in the B2B space. Salesforce has gone on a shopping spree and most recently acquired a business for $17 billion dollars — Tableau, and they acquired MuleSoft for seven billion dollars. We're seeing really crazy acquisitions and a lot of that is tied to growth rate, so while I'm totally with you — we're in this fun part of the cycle — we do need to focus on efficiency growth still remains — Omeed Malik:Right, you don't want to remain so focused on that so that you lose the growth is what you're saying. You've got to find that happy medium. Maybe we went too far but you don't want to pendulum to swing all the way to the other side. Ben Hindman:That's exactly right, and it's all about unit economics as Ryan talked about earlier. You can do this, especially with the SaaS model, the revenue stacking. Ryan Denehy:If your right side up on your unit economics and you're looking at a company that's roughly at our stage, as an investor you can always underwrite to a 10x or more return because there's a clear machine that's working. You put a dollar in on one side and two's gonna come out the other and so I think where the market's headed right now is any astute investor is looking at a company and basically saying 'does the math add up' and so if you've got a really repeatable and profitable go to market motion, even the company itself is not profitable if the growth levers are profitable that typically presents a pretty clear path to upside. Omeed Malik:The statistics are demonstrating as I started from the outset that companies are staying private a lot longer. Maybe in the 'old days' end quote you would get your venture money and then within a few years there would be an exit. That's simply not happening anymore at least when it relates to IPOs and public markets, public exits. Does that change the way you think about building a business now because maybe that option is not as imminent as it once was? Cheih Huang:I think it certainly does. Now that we're five, six years in, as we think about that being a kind of potential option in the future for us you definitely want to tune your growth rate so that you're not burning out so by the time you do make it public you're having a growth rate that's trailing off. And also you want to build a business so that you actually have predictable growth, predictable margins, because in recent IPOs anyone who misses in their first year you see the stock never really recovers. So really being ready for that moment on a dime and if your basis points know what you're going to do next quarter is something that, say, when we were two years old we certainly could not do. So that's what we're driving for. Ryan Denehy:For both founders and investors the asset class overall has matured quite a bit even in the last five years. So for early investors in companies like ours the opportunity is to actually achieve liquidity in the absence of an IPO or some type of exit event. Those things are relatively commonplace now and they weren't five or seven years ago. And so I think for founders it creates a lot more optionality because you can take a much longer view to how you run the business. At the same time you don't have to hamstring people on your cap table. We've got some early investors in our company that may choose to take a little bit of their position off the table in the next round — not because they don't believe it the business — but just because for their mix and their allocation that's what they want to do. Five or ten years ago you couldn't do that. You either had to go for the quick flip or you were in it for the long haul. Now it's a more friendly environment for all types of investors. Omeed Malik:That's a really important point, and I should have mentioned it earlier on. One of the reasons we have a business at Farvahar is not only to what you're describing, but the liquidity that you now have a robust secondary market that's actually developing as well. That's a game changer to create parallel market in the private space, where even as — forget about insiders and employees which are imperative — but now you can have speculators come in, and buy and sell before an exit as well. That also creates a situation where these companies are going to be able to stay private a lot longer. It's just another infusion of capital. Dan Teran:I think you're also seeing for employees there's liquidity options that didn't used to exist, so in the form of speculators, but also tender offers are becoming sort of commonplace for later state private companies. I think all of these things create a healthier late state private ecosystem. Omeed Malik:Right, because otherwise that was a huge issue with attrition. If you can't get these people the exit, they can't afford to make the first house purchase or what have you and now there are options for them. I think that's another really really important and positive development, and then not to mention with rates where they are you're still going to have people searching for yield and they're going to come into this area too. It's all interconnected, and that's why it's funny when I talk to people they say 'well this just happened' well what happened was it's been going to fifteen or twenty years, you're just seeing the maturation of it now. I do want to pose a policy question and it might not be the right audience with you guys, but when you think about majors buying these niche-y businesses at huge premiums and eating them up, it's a good thing for the owner and probably the company, but do you worry about the majors now — the incumbents creating these monopolies that actually stifle innovation in a way? Ben Hindman:Certainly, it's a very challenging time to build a start-up in a lot of ways. We started off in 2012, and I think it would be a very different thing to try to start a business today than when we were starting. Dan Teran: Well it's a lot easier. Ben Hindman: You think today it's easier? Dan Teran: It's way easier today. Ben Hindman: Say more. Dan Teran:All of the building blocks, even web services weren't fully fleshed out when we started our businesses, and so I think there's so many building blocks to build a company today that didn't used to exist. Even the things that we built help build their companies faster and more effectively. I think in terms of the M...ctivity and so the fact that the specter always looms that you might get a very attractive offer from a very big tech company actually is causing more people to start companies. So in a way it's good for the ecosystem, and I think as a founder and as an executive it is your choice to take that offer or to decide whether to go it alone. Cheih is probably a great example. People I am sure have told him for the better part of the last decade that he's an idiot for trying to compete with Amazon, but if he let that drive his thinking he would have never got out of bed. He's built an incredible business. Cheih Huang:Thank you Dan. I think when it comes at least part of the industry that our company touches — consumer packaged goods — I don't think you're going to see a massive massive CPG company come anytime soon solely because of that dynamic. Anytime you have any modicum of success with package goods, whether it's George Clooney with tequila, or whether it's Harry's with razors, someone comes in and snaps it up. So I'd be very surprised in the next ten years if your a vertically integrated brand selling a certain product in the CPG market that you'd actually grow to a ten billion plus market cap. Omeed Malik:I think you're totally accurate. That raises less policy questions though than Facebook buying up unrelated things maybe like Instagram. Dan Teran:That poses broader questions for the average person, but I think as a founder it actually makes it more attractive to start a company because it just gives you more options. Ryan Denehy:Yeah ultimately if you look at Facebook and you look at Google — Google has somehow figured out how to build technology that has harnessed all of the world's web searches and still all they've managed to do is sell advertising with the data and Facebook — same way. So once we step outside of this digital ad ecosystem the barriers to entry — to starting a company and acquiring a customer — are the lowest they've ever been. So what we'll start to see in B2B software, in CPG, is actually increasing fragmentation and less likely to see a monopolistic structure in a lot of these businesses. Omeed Malik:Given everything we've talked about, how have your thoughts about an ideal cap table evolved? You hear some of these — when we talk about the negative connotations associated with this market, it's a company that isn't really a tech company but it's just a marketing/branding company that doesn't do anything different and has a bunch of influencers and celebrities on their cap table. How do you do everything in your power to not be that? Ryan Denehy:We need strong governance. What any investor in this room or outside of the room doesn't want is some egotistical founder who's going to run their company into the ground. So I think even in our case — we have some outstanding investors — one of the things I did was worked with my investors in the last round to actually institute more mature governance around board structure and terms for the round because ultimately what that signals to investors in later rounds is that this is a grown-up business that is taking a long view on what they want to do. I can probably speak for all of us here, I don't think we would want to be going to market with supervoting shares and total control over our companies. Cheih Huang:How our cap table has evolved has been pretty interesting as well. We had a board member come into one of our recent board meetings, and said — because we have early stage folks on the board, we have mid-stage financial investors, we have the largest retailer in Asia on our board, American Express is on our board — so one of our board members walked in and was like 'dude, whenever I walk into the boardroom at a Boxed board meeting it feels like I walked into the Star Wars bar. Every species in the universe is here.' But it's made for really good debate and so I think if you just have early stage financial investors then every day there's going to be Medium articles they're going to forward you on how to run your business, and if it's just strategies they also don't know what it's like to run an early stage business, so kind of having that diversity of thought is pretty important. Dan Teran:I'm beginning to feel I'm a bad luck charm, because we did a deal with Staples and within two months they were taken private and the entire executive team was fired. So the executive team that we did the deal with Staples with was very different than the one that remained going forward but we actually found them to be a good partner, they participated in our Series C, they had a board seat, and we had a bit of a distribution partnership with them but with the regime change and they had a lot of layoffs on their end it didn't end up being quite what we had intended. But I would say when choosing a corporate capital venture partner, I think long-term alignment around the customer is really important and we felt like that was the case with them. Omeed Malik:There's no doubt that — again this is kind of a manifestation of it — that these lines are all being blurred tremendously and we're seeing that play out on cap tables. Ben Hindman:I guess I would call out — just because we're at this conference — the ability to hit a new market can be totally unlocked by a new investor. We just came into AMEA, we brought in a strategic in order to go attack that market and it was fundamentally a game changer for us. So certainly a conference like this, coming into AMEA, that's a value that many investors could offer. Omeed Malik:No interview with CEOs is complete without asking about culture. You just have to ask it, it's the number one clich. So, let me just put a twist on that: how overrated is culture? Is it just B.S.? Ryan Denehy:I think really what you're talking about is leadership the best companies on the planet tend to have world-class leadership teams. You're not really going to accomplish anything great without phenomenal people. So my point of view generally on culture is that it starts by building a phenomenal, cohesive leadership team — challenging themselves to solve the problems together. The culture — at least in our business — winds up being the byproduct of these things that you do, these incredible people. So from that perspective I don't think it's overrated, I think that the leadership and the culture is the business. Often though, in Silicon Valley culture is bean bag chairs and ping pong tables and free lunch — that's probably the wrong type of culture. Dan Teran:I think I would say, I've seen at companies be built two types of ways: one is you have this great idea, insane product market fit out of the gates, and you are literally building a machine to execute that one thing. What you get there can be a very frail organization because the thing was built to literally do one thing and one thing only, versus building what I think is a better type of culture: you build an organization that ingests and solves problems together, and what you get is resiliency. So when the business changes, things aren't going so well, you have a team that hangs together and figures out how to solve problems together. I think there's been plenty of shakeouts recently, lots of companies that don't need to be named at a big scale where not having a really strong culture has created a lot of issues through challenging times and I would say one of things that have been great in the last six months at my company, at Managed by Q is the team's hung together. I mean they've worked together for a long time, they want to stick together, and as we're looking at this spinout option I have recruiters telling me that they can hire from any of the other subsidiaries, but when they call my engineers they are gonna wait and see what happens, because they don't want to leave. I think that's something that you only get from investing in culture over a long period of time. Omeed Malik:It's purely coincidental — we didn't think about it when we put you guys together — but all of you are based in New York, not San Francisco. What does that say? Cheih Huang:It says there's life in tech outside of San Francisco and that the market is maturing. Most of us on this stage if not all of us are multi-time founders now, having collectively raised probably getting close to a billion dollars these days, and that you can build companies anywhere in the world, whether be it New York or Abu Dhabi. Dan Teran:One of the things that's unique about all of our businesses is that I actually believe none of us would have been funded as first-time early entrepreneurs in San Francisco with the businesses we were pitching then. So we all built businesses that were solving a problem for a customer but didn't fit the mold of the traditional Silicon Valley SaaS pitch. We've iterated and figured it out and built great businesses, but actually I think being in New York was an advantage for us. Ryan Denehy:In San Francisco everyone is trying so hard to be different that they all wind up being the sam. The point that I made earlier is that in New York the money's the same color — if you're going after a huge market with a compelling business model, just because it doesn't fit the perfect B2B software mold a Bay Area investor is looking for, well in New York it kind of doesn't matter. If it's a great team and a great market people want in. Cheih Huang:It's changed over time too, because when we first started we weren't based in New York, we were based in Jersey as I said, and getting a Silicon Valley investor to come visit you in New Jersey was impossible. They're like, 'I go for one reason and that's Newark airport, and I hate it, so I'm not going to add a second that I'm going to hate as well.' Ben Hindman:Let's just quickly call it out: work is changing. About half my company doesn't work in New York, but we're headquartered there because that's where our potential clients are, or many of which are. So we're just seeing a totally different way of hiring and I think that's going tomake it so that it kind of doesn't matter where you are. Omeed Malik:Before I let you guys go, give me a contrarian view that you have that makes your businesses would still work though despite it. Dan Teran:The bet that we made six years ago, seven years ago when we started working on Q was that the workplace still matters. So to Ben's point, you can work anywhere. We fundamentally believe that the best work and the highest leverage people are always going to work in a workplace together and solve problems together. So, one of the things we were told is that with this rise of remote culture we were building a business that wouldn't matter, and our point of view was that's just not true. Fortunately, we're seeing companies spend more on their offices per employee every single year and seems to be panning out. I think with WeWork there's still an incredible business in there, and I think they really hit the nail on the head in terms of the zeitgeist of making the workplace experience something that attracts and retains talent and makes people excited to show up to work rather than go work in a cube. Ryan Denehy:In our case, sometimes the way to build a world-class software company is actually to start with a lot of people and services first, use that to actually create a data asset that you can use to map out the software that you want to build and then automate it away over time. It's a little backwards but it's worked quite well for us. Cheih Huang:For me, it would be online commerce is so large, if you focus on specific regions in the world or specific use cases within an industry you can still build a gigantic company doing so. Ben Hindman:Ours is we operate in a relatively crowded space. Our customers don't see it that way. I was told that last night by Tim Draper. He said 'oh that's a pretty crowded space you're in.' I said I'm going to have to win it I guess. Dan Teran:No customer ever describes a space as crowded. Ben Hindman:That's right. I think we are fundamentally at a shift in technology that allows totally new solutions to come into play, and we're showing that. Omeed Malik:Well, guys, this was awesome. Thank you very much for making the trip out here and please join me in thanking them for their time. Follow Omeed Malik on his Website[3] and Twitter[4]. Read more: From Venture capital to growth equity - Founders perspective on today's capital markets[5] [ 1]: https://www.farvaharpartners.com/ [ 2]:   https://www.youtube.com/embed/1Wr6r2KnaVY [ 3]:   http://omeedmalikadvisors.com/ [ 4]:   https://twitter.com/realomeedmalik [ 5]:   https://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/business/from-venture-capital-to-growth-equity-founders-perspective-on-todays-capital-markets/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60MR-P6W1-DYT4-K02X-00000-00From virtual to real battle, and Apple knows it will be an epic2020-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:25ZLexisNexisSCIENCE & TECHNOLOGYPg. 13From virtual to real battle, and Apple knows it will be an epicKate Thompson Davy

From virtual to real battle, and Apple knows it will be an

epic

With legal action Epic Games joins ranks of those accusing tech giant of

uncompetitive ways Two

months ago I wrote about the accusations of anticompetitive behaviour flying thick

and fast at Apple, among others. Now Epic Games has entered the fray, refocused

players, and it looks like a battle is shaping up.

One of the primary

complaints is that the 30% commission charged by Apple on in-app purchases creates an

uneven playing ground for digital goods that compete with ones from Apple. For

example, Japanese firm Rakuten, which owns Kobo e-readers and books, said this extra

cost makes it hard for its e-books to compete on price with Apple Books

products.

This was closely aligned with what Spotify has raised against Apple

Music, suggesting the policy "deliberately disadvantage[s] other app developers".

Apple has denied being anticompetitive, arguing instead that it has facilitated

$519bn in "billings and sales globally" in 2019, and the vast majority ended in the

pockets of "third-party developers and businesses of all sizes".

LOCATION DATA

Then in July, Apple's Tim Cook and his handful of tech giant peers were

called before a US house judiciary subcommittee. The Republican members got stuck on

whether "big tech" was unfairly targeting conservatives (spoiler alert: all research

suggests not), but thankfully some kept their focus on possible antitrust and

related abuses of their dominance.

Cook arguably came off the best prepared of

the bunch, but the matter is continuing with follow-up questions being tabled,

including whether Apple is making money off iPhone location data.

So, as I

said, "the regulators are coming for big tech", but those wheels turn slowly. The

private sector can act with agility and deadly aim. And that's what Epic Games

did last week when it knowingly defied Apple app and Google Play store rules and

implemented a direct payment option in the Fortnite apps for iPhone and iPad and for

Android devices. Through this option, players can get in-game currency known as V-

Bucks at a 20% discount compared with that paid when the traditional in-app purchase

route is taken.

This was a deliberate move, a shift into challenger mode, as

someone inclined to make too many gaming puns might say. The ballsy gambit came after

months of trying to win ground behind the scenes amid escalating tensions, and it

resulted in Apple removing Fortnite from the App Store.

"Epic has had apps on

the App Store for a decade, and have benefited from the App Store ecosystem -

including its tools, testing, and distribution that Apple provides to all

developers," Apple said in a statement.

"Epic agreed to the App Store terms and

guidelines freely and we're glad they've built such a successful

business on the App Store," it said.

Epic volleyed with a lawsuit in which it

submitted that "Apple has become what it once railed against: the behemoth seeking to

control markets, block competition and stifle innovation", and asked the judge to

prevent Apple from taking retaliatory action against Epic's other games in the

store.

To add insult to injury, Epic also produced a video, Nineteen Eighty-

Fortnite, directly parodying a vintage Apple ad, which in turn referenced the post-

apocalyptic classic Nineteen-Eighty Four novel. It's not a legal win, sure,

but it was an inspired moment of cultural critique for the #freefortnite crew. You

can find both ads on YouTube, and they are worth a watch if media intertextuality is

your vibe.

This isn't just another company adding its name to the anti-

30% club. Look, none of them are small fry, but Epic is a biggie. Fortnite is huge

- with millions of players and dollar revenues in the billions. It is also the

name behind Unreal Engine, a 3D real-time creation tool that powers other games. Any

win by them is likely to be to the benefit of the larger game development

community.

What the legislators make of it remains to be seen, but on the

principles, what is fair in this regard? It's hard to say, especially when the

market is concentrated and the "landlord" you rent your space from is also part-

promoter, part-salesman, and the payment facilitator.

There is no doubt that

Apple has created an incredible marketplace for app developers, including gamers, and

it deserves something commercially meaningful for that. Can a third be justified,

though? It's a chunk of change in a booming business place.

Thompson

Davy, a freelance journalist, is an impactAFRICA fellow and WanaData member.

Not fair: A visitor uses a Kobo Touch e-reader

displayed in the Rakuten booth at the 16th e-Book Expo Tokyo in Japan. Kobo says it

is hard to compete with Apple books due to its hefty levy.

Bloomberg

Extracts.SummaryText: ... regulatory overhaul finally get over the line? And, if so, how far will it go? Will the titans be broken up, or forced to change their ways under threat of huge financial penalties? For clues, look no further than Lina Khan, a 31-yearold lawyer who helped set in motion the reckoning three years ago. While a law student, Khan wrote an article for The Yale Law Journal titled Amazon 's Anti-trust Paradox . She argued that the legal conventions that had held since the 1970s had been lapped by the

<xhtml:span id="h1" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... Facebook , Google and Amazon , was remarkable. For <xhtml:span class="hit">Big Tech</xhtml:span> 's critics, it is the surest sign yet that the years ...</xhtml:span>

urn:contentItem:606S-X7P1-DY2T-F2N9-00000-00From yale law to big tech headache; How lina khan set the anti-trust push in motion2020-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:25ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. FP1 From yale law to big tech headache; How lina khan set the anti-trust push in motionDanny FortsonNational PostSan Francisco

The worm appears to have turned. In the week that Margrethe Vestager, the EU's top competition cop, launched a market abuse investigation into Apple, David Cicilline, the congressman leading a Big Tech probe in America, accused his country's biggest company of "highway robbery" over the 30 per cent cut it takes from the cash generated by its App Store.

Even Microsoft president Brad Smith, who spent a quarter of a century in an anti-trust fight with Washington, said the "time has come" for the authorities to look into just how Apple does business.

The sudden turn against the iPhone maker, which has avoided the slings and arrows aimed at Facebook, Google and Amazon, was remarkable. For Big Tech's critics, it is the surest sign yet that the years of hand-wringing are over. The West Coast giants, they claim, are about to be walloped by a regulatory crackdown not seen in decades.

The showdown will even come with a photo op. Some time in the next few weeks, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Jeff Bezos at Amazon and Sundar Pichai of Google parent Alphabet will, for the first time, testify together in Congress. Apple's Tim Cook is the only one who has not confirmed his appearance, although Cicilline expects him to show up for a lineup that will be redolent of the appearances of Big Tobacco executives in the 1990s, or Wall Street chief executives after the financial crisis.

"I expect we'll have all four CEOs there," Cicilline told The Vergecast podcast. "This is the Congress of the United States conducting its first major anti-trust investigation in 50 years and their testimony is essential to completing this properly."

Will it be different this time? Will the long-promised regulatory overhaul finally get over the line? And, if so, how far will it go? Will the titans be broken up, or forced to change their ways under threat of huge financial penalties? For clues, look no further than Lina Khan, a 31-yearold lawyer who helped set in motion the reckoning three years ago. While a law student, Khan wrote an article for The Yale Law Journal titled Amazon's Anti-trust Paradox. She argued that the legal conventions that had held since the 1970s had been lapped by the Big Tech platforms.

The article stoked a debate that still rages. For decades the guiding anti-trust principle in America has been narrow and simple: consumer welfare. If you were not using your power to overcharge customers, you were fine.

Khan argued that Amazon was different: its empire is so vast, the data on its customers so granular, that it can wield its power in an array of ways to suffocate competitors, reduce choice and hurt consumers. She wrote: "The current framework in anti-trust - specifically its pegging competition to 'consumer welfare', defined as short-term price effects - is unequipped to capture the architecture of market power in the modern economy."

To wit, a recent Wall Street Journal investigation found that the US$1.3 trillion giant mined data from third-party sellers to create rival products, contradicting its own stated policies.

Republican senator Orrin Hatch dismissed Khan's ideas as "hipster anti-trust." The hipster, however, has made it inside the building. Since last year, Khan has been a staff lawyer for Cicilline's House anti-trust subcommittee, helping shape the questions his bipartisan group will ask and the recommendations it will publish to rein in the top platforms.

Her rise is something of a victory for Barry Lynn, who hired Khan in 2011 as a junior researcher at the New America think-tank, where he ran the anti-trust policy unit. Back then, "I was kind of alone", Lynn said.

He had been arguing for a decade that anti-trust policy needed to go back to its roots, when the government broke up the railroads and telecoms monopolies. The problem, he said, was a "revolution in thinking" that took hold in 1978. That was when Robert Bork, a libertarian legal scholar, wrote The Antitrust Paradox.

The book elevated consumer welfare as the guiding principle, and sidelined protection of competition.

The revolution was subtle, done not through the creation of a new body or dissolution of another, but by a shift in interpretation. It was embraced by politicians and the courts, setting the stage for the mega-mergers of the 1980s and a gradual consolidation of power across industries, including the internet.

Lynn, who now runs the Open Markets Institute, argued that another shift was in order. "We don't need new laws, we don't need new institutions," he said. What was required was a new lens through which to view - and regulate - the digital giants. Khan did not respond to a request for comment, but it appears that her ideas have helped guide the House subcommittee's thinking. A source said Cicilline's group was looking at how best to transform predatory pricing and other potential abuses back into grounds for action against companies, including potentially breaking them up.

The source added: "We have been through a 40-year lobotomy where our anti-trust laws were gutted and the core philosophy often promotes monopoly rather than targeting it. The committee wants to recover the traditional tool box that we've had for addressing problems of dominance and private concentrations of economic power."

Last Monday, David Heinemeier Hansson launched a $99-a-year email service, called Hey. When his company, Basecamp, attempted to put an update through the App Store to fix a small bug, Apple said no. Unless Hey required users to sign up for the paid service though the App Store - rather than Hey's website - it could not update the app. For Apple, it was no small matter. The company requires all apps to hand over 30 per cent of any revenue: the cost of admission into one of the world's biggest storefronts. Heinemeier Hansson branded Apple a "mafioso." Cicilline called the 30 per cent cut "unconscionable."

Tech commentator Ben Thompson said he had heard dozens of similar stories: Apple using the app approval process to ensure it gets its money. "This is not an accident, but a co-ordinated campaign to drive more App Store revenue," he wrote in his Stratechery newsletter.

"The number of ways that Apple can retaliate are so varied and hard to verify that no one is willing to publicly breathe a word against the company."

Apple is not alone in this.

Amazon also levies hefty fees on third parties that sell via its site. This is the core around which the crackdown appears to be crystallizing. Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook are very different businesses, but they all act as "gatekeepers," controlling the exchange of goods and adverts and ideas online.

Lynn said: "They are the master middlemen of our time." He is betting, however, that their time is almost up.

An Rong Xu For The Washington Post; Lina Khan wrote about Amazon and anti-trust for the Yale Law Journal. That was just the beginning.; Paul Sakuma , The Associated Press Files; A recent Wall Street Journal investigation found Amazon mines data from third-party sellers to create rival products, contradicting its own stated policies.;
